title: BDT Capital Takes  Control of Culligan,  Valued at $6 Billion  ----  By Miriam Gottfried
text:
BDT Capital Partners LLC is taking a majority stake in Culligan International Co., becoming the latest in a string of private-equity firms to own the water-treatment specialist, officials from the companies said.

The parties aren't disclosing terms of the deal, but a person familiar with the matter said it values Culligan at $6 billion, including debt.

Advent International Corp., Culligan's current majority owner, plans to reinvest in the business and hold a minority stake.

Based in Rosemont, Ill., Culligan sells products and services for water filtration and treatment. Founded in 1936 as a maker of water softeners, its product lineup now includes items as simple as water-filter pitchers and as complex as whole-house and business-filtration systems. Culligan offers monthly service contracts with most of its products, accounting for about 65% of sales and generating the steady cash flows that private equity prizes.

It has more than 7,500 employees and 1,000 dealers in 90 countries, making it one of the largest players in what the company estimates is a $35 billion global market for consumer water services.

Under Advent's ownership, Culligan's revenue has tripled, thanks to an aggressive M&A strategy and high-single-digit organic growth. Culligan has done 90 acquisitions since Advent bought it in 2016, primarily of small, family-owned companies in markets like Germany, Italy and Spain.

In 2019, Culligan announced a deal to buy AquaVenture Holdings Ltd., a publicly traded U.S. maker of bottle-free water coolers, for $1.1 billion including debt. It has also expanded into pitchers and machines that dispense filtered water, such as those that might be found in an airport.

Culligan Chief Executive Scott Clawson, hired to run the company in 2012, credits private-equity ownership with enabling it to expand.

"We had a lot of access to capital to continue to grow," Mr. Clawson, a Danaher Corp. and Alcoa Corp. veteran, said in an interview. "This is an area where private equity really adds a ton of value."

People are drinking fewer soft drinks and juices and turning to water as a more healthful alternative as they increasingly eschew plastic bottles either because of regulations, a desire to protect the environment or concerns about ingesting chemicals, he said.

The sale marks a big win for Advent, which bought Culligan from Centerbridge LP in a deal that valued the company at about $915 million including debt. Centerbridge retained a minority stake and will be exiting as part of the sale to BDT.

Founded in 1984, Advent is one of the most global private-equity firms, having invested in more than 375 companies in 42 countries. It manages about $76 billion across five sectors: business and financial services; healthcare; industrial; retail, consumer and leisure; and technology.

BDT Capital is affiliated with merchant bank BDT & Co., which specializes in advising and investing in family- and founder-led businesses. Its founder, Byron Trott, formerly of Goldman Sachs Group Inc., is known as the favorite banker of famed investor Warren Buffett.

The firm will acquire Culligan alongside several family-business owners and investors including Abu Dhabi sovereign-wealth fund Mubadala Investment Co.

Chicago-based BDT has raised over $18 billion across its funds and has placed more than $7 billion of co-investments with its investors.

The firm will help Culligan continue its existing strategy and expand into new geographies, said Mr. Clawson.
